title: Constructor permits threshold=0 when owners.length=1 (bypasses signature requirement)
summary: The multisig wallet constructor validation allows threshold=0 when deployed with a single owner due to integer division truncation in the minimum threshold check. This completely bypasses the signature verification requirement in the execute() function.

vulnerability_details.root_cause: Integer division truncation in constructor validation

execute_function_impact.signature_loop: for (i = 0; i < threshold; i++) { validate signature[i] }
execute_function_impact.when_threshold_0: Loop executes 0 times, no signatures validated
execute_function_impact.result: Any call to execute() succeeds without any signature verification

exploit_scenario.step_2: Fund the multisig with valuable assets
exploit_scenario.step_3: Attacker calls execute([], [], [], attacker, balance, '', attacker, 1000000)
exploit_scenario.step_5: ETH/tokens transferred to attacker without any valid signature

error_signatures.0xf02e8ac1: InvalidParams (threshold too low or owners invalid)

risk_assessment.new_deployments: CRITICAL - if deployed with owners=1, threshold=0 is possible
risk_assessment.factory_contracts: HIGH - any factory using this bytecode could create vulnerable instances

recommendations: Add explicit check: require(threshold > 0, 'threshold must be positive')
Audit any factory contracts that deploy this multisig code
Review all deployments to ensure none have threshold=0
